<form onsubmit="event.preventDefault(); checkAnswer('module7_mcq_q2')" data-correct-answer="B">
<strong style="display: block;">In perfect capital markets, the weighted average cost of capital (WACC):</strong>

<label><input type="radio" name="module7_mcq_q2" value="A"> A. Decreases as debt increases</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module7_mcq_q2" value="B"> B. Remains constant regardless of leverage</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module7_mcq_q2" value="C"> C. Increases as the firm issues more equity</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module7_mcq_q2" value="D"> D. Equals the cost of debt</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module7_mcq_q2" value="E"> E. Depends on dividends paid</label><br>
</form>

<div id="feedback-module7_mcq_q2" class="feedback" data-status="" style="display:none;">
✅ Correct: B. In a perfect market, leverage changes only the risk allocation, not total expected return—so WACC is constant.
